ARTICLE.TITLE: Police: Nashville teen's family, friend aided him in eluding capture after escape from juvenile detention
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Nashville police have said for days that the teens who escaped juvenile custody could not have successfully eluded capture without the help of adults.

On Friday, investigators began detailing what type of help adults provided some of the teens and who was involved.

Police arrested a cousin, a family friend and the mother of one of the teens who fled a juvenile detention center on Nov. 30, alleging that each provided either food, housing or technology for 15-year-old Calvin Howse while he evaded officers.

KEEP UP WITH DEVELOPMENTS:Get alerts you want on the free Tennessean news app

Howse and Decorrius Wright, 16, were apprehended Tuesday night in Madison. The other two teens who escaped custody — Morris Marsh and Brandon Caruthers, both 17 — remained at large Friday.

Howse's mother Danielle Horton, 33, cousin Tyrone Anderson, 29, and friend Brandi Lyonn, 35, were in custody, police said in a news release.

Jasmine Howse, 18, the sister of Calvin Howse, surrendered to downtown police on Friday on an outstanding warrant charging her with being an accessory after the fact of her brother’s escape and facilitation of escape.

Police say that when Calvin Howse was captured in Madison on Tuesday night, he was carrying a cellphone that investigators used to develop charges against the adults:

Anderson not only knew about Calvin Howse's whereabouts but assisted in getting the teen food and other items while Anderson was with Horton and Jasmine Howse, according to court records. Anderson also assisted in giving Calvin access to an Xfinity Wi-Fi account so that Calvin Howse could have internet access, police said.

Horton knew about Calvin’s whereabouts and assisted in giving him food and other items while she was with Anderson and Jasmine Howse, police claim.

Jenkins allowed Calvin to sleep at her house and also helped Horton get food for him, according to court documents.

Bond for Jasmin Howse, Horton, Anderson and Lynn is set for $10,000 each.

Police continue to search for Marsh and Caruthers. Anyone who may have seen them or know about their whereabouts is asked to contact Crime Stoppers at 615-742-7463.

There is a reward leading to each capture in excess of $5,000.
